takeAction.blurb: **Support climate action.** Help your city, country, or company achieve the commitments of the Paris Climate Agreement and the 2030 United Nations Sustainable Development Goals.
**Support ocean protection.** Help your country meet the IUCN 2030 goal of 30 percent Marine Protected Area coverage in the ocean.
**Support healthy fisheries.** Help your friends and family use the ocean wisely by choosing sustainable seafood, and by choosing not to eat coral reef fishes.
**Learn more** about the work of Dr. Kristen Marhaver at her lab’s website.

nodes.whoTheyAre: TED Senior Fellow Kristen Marhaver is a marine biologist studying the ecology, behavior and reproduction of reef corals.
nodes.whyListen:
Dr. Kristen Marhaver's work combines classic scientific methods with new technologies to help threatened coral species survive their early life stages. She was the first person to rear juveniles of the endangered Caribbean Pillar Coral. Now she's now developing bacterial tools to improve coral survival at all life stages.

Marhaver's research has been covered by NPR, BBC, The Atlantic and Popular Science, among hundreds of outlets. She's earned five fellowships and grants from the US National Science Foundation and multiple awards for science communication. Marhaver is a TED Senior Fellow, a WINGS Fellow, and a World Economic Forum Young Scientist.

Outside the lab, Marhaver advocates for stronger ocean conservation and smarter science communication. Her talks and articles have been featured by Google, Wired UK, Mission Blue and by ocean and scuba festivals around the world.

A scuba diver from the age of 15, Marhaver is a graduate of Georgia Institute of Technology and the Center for Marine Biodiversity and Conservation at Scripps Institution of Oceanography. Her lab is based at the CARMABI Research Station on the island of Curaçao.

videoData.description: Corals in the Pacific Ocean have been dying at an alarming rate, particularly from bleaching brought on by increased water temperatures. But it's not too late to act, says TED Fellow Kristen Marhaver. She points to the Caribbean -- given time, stable temperatures and strong protection, corals there have shown the ability to survive and recover from trauma. Marhaver reminds us why we need to keep working to protect the precious corals we have left. "Corals have always been playing the long game," she says, "and now so are we."

cues.text: The first time I cried underwater
was in 2008,
the island of Curaçao,
way down in the southern Caribbean.
It's beautiful there.
I was studying these corals for my PhD,

and after days and days
of diving on the same reef,
I had gotten to know them as individuals.
I had made friends with coral colonies --
totally a normal thing to do.

Then, Hurricane Omar smashed them apart
and ripped off their skin,

leaving little bits of wounded tissue
that would have a hard time healing,

and big patches of dead skeleton
that would get overgrown by algae.
When I saw this damage for the first time,
stretching all the way down the reef,
I sunk onto the sand in my scuba gear
and I cried.
If a coral could die that fast,
how could a reef ever survive?

And why was I making it my job
to try to fight for them?

I never heard another scientist
tell that kind of story
until last year.
A scientist in Guam wrote,
"I cried right into my mask,"
seeing the damage on the reefs.
Then a scientist in Australia wrote,

"I showed my students
the results of our coral surveys,
and we wept."

Crying about corals
is having a moment, guys.
(Laughter)
And that's because reefs in the Pacific

are losing corals faster
than we've ever seen before.
Because of climate change,

the water is so hot for so long
in the summers,

that these animals
can't function normally.

They're spitting out the colored algae
that lives in their skin,

and the clear bleached tissue
that's left usually starves to death
and then rots away.
Then the skeletons are overgrown by algae.

This is happening
over an unbelievable scale.

The Northern Great Barrier Reef
lost two-thirds of its corals last year
over a distance of hundreds of miles,
then bleached again this year,
and the bleaching stretched further south.

Reefs in the Pacific
are in a nosedive right now,

and no one knows
how bad it's going to get,
except ...
over in the Caribbean where I work,
we've already been through the nosedive.

Reefs there have suffered
through centuries of intense human abuse.

We kind of already know
how the story goes.

And we might be able to help predict
what happens next.
Let's consult a graph.
Since the invention of scuba,

scientists have measured
the amount of coral on the seafloor,
and how it's changed through time.

And after centuries
of ratcheting human pressure,
Caribbean reefs met one of three fates.
Some reefs lost their corals very quickly.
Some reefs lost their corals more slowly,
but kind of ended up in the same place.
OK, so far this is not going very well.
But some reefs in the Caribbean --
the ones best protected

and the ones a little
further from humans --
they managed to hold onto their corals.
Give us a challenge.
And, we almost never saw a reef hit zero.
The second time I cried underwater
was on the north shore of Curaçao, 2011.
It was the calmest day of the year,

but it's always pretty
sketchy diving there.
My boyfriend and I swam against the waves.

I watched my compass
so we could find our way back out,
and he watched for sharks,

and after 20 minutes of swimming
that felt like an hour,
we finally dropped down to the reef,
and I was so shocked,
and I was so happy
that my eyes filled with tears.

There were corals 1,000 years old
lined up one after another.

They had survived the entire history
of European colonialism in the Caribbean,
and for centuries before that.

I never knew what a coral could do
when it was given a chance to thrive.

The truth is that even
as we lose so many corals,

even as we go through
this massive coral die-off,
some reefs will survive.
Some will be ragged on the edge,
some will be beautiful.

And by protecting shorelines
and giving us food to eat
and supporting tourism,

they will still be worth
billions and billions of dollars a year.

The best time to protect a reef
was 50 years ago,
but the second-best time is right now.
Even as we go through bleaching events,
more frequent and in more places,
some corals will be able to recover.

We had a bleaching event
in 2010 in the Caribbean

that took off big patches of skin
on boulder corals like these.
This coral lost half of its skin.

But if you look at the side
of this coral a few years later,
this coral is actually healthy again.
It's doing what a healthy coral does.
It's making copies of its polyps,
it's fighting back the algae
and it's reclaiming its territory.
If a few polyps survive,
a coral can regrow;

it just needs time and protection
and a reasonable temperature.
Some corals can regrow in 10 years --
others take a lot longer.

But the more stresses
we take off them locally --

things like overfishing,
sewage pollution, fertilizer pollution,
dredging, coastal construction --

the better they can hang on
as we stabilize the climate,
and the faster they can regrow.

And as we go through the long,
tough and necessary process

of stabilizing the climate
of planet Earth,
some new corals will still be born.
This is what I study in my research.

We try to understand
how corals make babies,

and how those babies
find their way to the reef,

and we invent new methods
to help them survive
those early, fragile life stages.

One of my favorite
coral babies of all time
showed up right after Hurricane Omar.

It's the same species
I was studying before the storm,

but you almost never see
babies of this species --
it's really rare.
This is actually an endangered species.

In this photo, this little baby coral,
this little circle of polyps,
is a few years old.
Like its cousins that bleach,
it's fighting back the algae.
And like its cousins on the north shore,
it's aiming to live for 1,000 years.

What's happening in the world
and in the ocean
has changed our time horizon.

We can be incredibly pessimistic
on the short term,
and mourn what we lost
and what we really took for granted.

But we can still be optimistic
on the long term,

and we can still be ambitious
about what we fight for
and what we expect from our governments,
from our planet.

Corals have been living on planet Earth
for hundreds of millions of years.

They survived the extinction
of the dinosaurs.
They're badasses.
(Laughter)

An individual coral can go through
tremendous trauma and fully recover

if it's given a chance
and it's given protection.

Corals have always
been playing the long game,
and now so are we.
Thanks very much.
(Applause)

footnotes.annotation:
> "… I cried underwater ..."

Can you cry underwater?

Can you cry while scuba diving? Can you throw up? Can you laugh? The answer is YES, to all of the above. But it can all be a bit risky. Your mask may fill with water or you may spit out your air regulator. You may cough, swallow sea water or panic. Crying underwater is possible, but NOT recommended!

> "… friends with individual coral colonies …"

Wait, what’s a coral again?

Before we dig in too far, let’s hit the basics. Corals are animals related to jellyfish and anemones; they’re all in the animal group [Cnidaria](http://ocean.si.edu/corals-and-coral-reefs). A single coral polyp looks like a tiny anemone with a mouth, stomach, and tentacles. One big difference between anemones and corals is that corals leave a calcium carbonate (limestone) skeleton underneath themselves as they grow. Corals are also clonal, that is, they make copies of themselves through budding or by dividing in half. And corals are colonial, meaning all the individuals live together in a colony. (So, imagine standing in one place, shoulder to shoulder with 1000 clones of yourself, growing a skeleton from your feet, and growing additional clones of yourself from your shoulders. Corals do things their own way!) The result is a big colony of coral polyps, all joined together side-by-side, building a complex limestone structure underneath. This limestone creates the structure of the coral reef and provides the homes for millions of other animals. Just as trees build the structure of a forest, corals build the structure of a coral reef.

> "… And then Hurricane Omar …"

Hurricane Omar damaged the shallow reefs of Curaçao

[Hurricane Omar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hurricane_Omar) caused three days of heavy storm surge on the shallow, protected coral reefs of Curaçao. Half of all corals in the shallow areas had some form of [tissue damage](http://www.versgeperst.com/nieuws/476/koraal-ernstig-beschadigd.html). Some coral colonies eventually recovered, but many others died in the next few months due to sediment stress, algal overgrowth, and bacterial infections in their damaged tissue.

>"… A scientist from Guam said I cried right into my mask …"

Scientists mourn coral bleaching in the Pacific

In August 2016, a scientist from the University of Guam described how she cried in her scuba mask at the sight of extensive coral bleaching.

Washington Post. 2016. ["'I cried…right into my mask': Scientists say Guam’s reefs have bleached four years straight"](https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/energy-environment/wp/2016/08/03/i-cried-right-into-my-mask-these-coral-reefs-have-seen-a-devastating-four-years-of-bleaching)

In April 2016, a professor from Australia described weeping with his students when they saw the result of coral bleaching surveys on the Great Barrier Reef.

Washington Post. 2016. ["'And then we wept': Scientists say 93 percent of the Great Barrier Reef now bleached"](https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/energy-environment/wp/2016/04/20/and-then-we-wept-scientists-say-93-percent-of-the-great-barrier-reef-now-bleached)

>"… Because of climate change, the water is too hot for too long …"

What is coral bleaching? 

A healthy coral animal has single-celled algae (known as dinoflagellates) living it its skin cells and producing sugars. (It would be like having plants living in your skin, constantly topping up your blood sugar, so you rarely or never had to eat.) It’s an amazing system, but also a delicate one. Under stressful conditions, especially heat stress, a coral ejects these symbiotic algae and loses its main source of food. This is known as [coral bleaching.](https://oceanservice.noaa.gov/facts/coral_bleach.html) After bleaching, the coral tissue is still alive, but it usually starves to death. Fortunately, some corals are able to re-cover their algal partners and continue growing. However, after such stress, these corals will grow more slowly in the years that follow.

>"… This is happening on an unbelievable scale …"

The Great Barrier Reef suffered the worst coral die-off ever recorded

Driven by climate change, warming seawater temperatures triggered a [global coral bleaching event](https://coralreefwatch.noaa.gov/satellite/analyses_guidance/global_coral_bleaching_2014-17_status.php) beginning in 2014. By 2016, unprecedented coral bleaching and death were occurring at locations all around the Pacific Ocean. The Northern section of the Great Barrier Reef lost two-thirds of its corals in 2016 alone, over a distance of [700 kilometers](https://theconversation.com/how-much-coral-has-died-in-the-great-barrier-reefs-worst-bleaching-event-69494), in the single largest coral die-off ever recorded. Another bleaching event occurred the following year, and this time, the severe bleaching stretched southward to the middle section of the [Great Barrier Reef](http://theconversation.com/back-to-back-bleaching-has-now-hit-two-thirds-of-the-great-barrier-reef-76092). Finally in June 2017, the Global Coral Bleaching event of 2014-2017 [began to ease](https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2017/jun/20/worst-global-coral-bleaching-event-eases-as-experts-await-next-one). However, the long-term damage is still unknown.

>"… Over in the Caribbean …"

Caribbean reefs have faced centuries of human pressure, yet healthy reefs remain

The arrival of European colonists in the Caribbean [accelerated and increased human pressure on the region’s fisheries and ecosystems](https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/historical-overfishing-st/) long before the invention of scuba and the beginning of modern coral reef studies. This has been documented through the work of historical ecologists such as Dr. Loren McClenachan and Dr. Jeremy Jackson. 

Recently, Dr. Jeremy Jackson led a [study](http://www.reefresilience.org/article-summaries/status-and-trends-of-caribbean-coral-reefs-1970-2012-executive-summary/) to compile and synthesize all long-term ecological data from coral reefs in the Caribbean. Since 1970, the Caribbean has lost huge amounts of coral, but the full story is much more nuanced. Some Caribbean reefs are virtually collapsed, stuck below 10% coral cover. But other reefs have remained stable, or even gained coral cover between [1970 and 2012](https://www.iucn.org/content/despair-repair-dramatic-decline-caribbean-corals-can-be-reversed). How did that happen? These reefs are usually in remote locations, or in locations that have strong marine protection, or in locations with low levels of corruption. This is an important illustration of the role of local factors in coral reef resilience. Another important conclusions from the study was that even the most degraded reefs held on to a handful of corals; even the most damaged locations have seeds for possible recovery. The lead authors on this study have called their findings, "From despair, to repair."

>"… The north shore of Curaçao …"

Remote regions of Curaçao still have healthy, growing coral reefs

[This coral](http://coral.org/coral-reefs-101/coral-reef-ecology/how-coral-reefs-grow) was photographed on the North Shore of Curaçao; at over 2 meters wide, it could easily be 1,000 years old. Here’s another 2-meter-wide colony of the same coral species, over in [Honduras](https://reefbuilders.com/2017/06/02/giant-orbicella-before-columbus/). One reason corals can grow so large on the North Shore of Curaçao is that this area is low coastal development and clean incoming water. But Curaçao also has impressive, [healthy coral populations](http://www.researchstationcarmabi.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/07/Vermeij-MJA-2012-Curacao-State-of-the-reef-2012-Carmabi-c2012.pdf) on the south shore, especially in Oostpunt (East Point) and on Klein Curaçao. Again, these are locations with very little coastal development. The lack of human pressure on shore allows these reefs to thrive, and to support fisheries and tourism just a few miles away from Curaçao capital city of Willemstad.

> "… The truth is … some coral reefs will survive …"

There is a very important caveat here: This history of the Caribbean doesn’t mean that reefs in the Pacific will follow the same trajectories, or in the same proportions. Climate change and thermal stress are making coral die-off in the Pacific much faster, and much worse. Some Pacific reefs will only begin to recover long after climate change is reversed. But the critical take-home here—missing from most journalism, but accepted among most scientists—is that coral reefs have hidden pockets of resilience. Stresses affect corals and coral reefs unevenly. This was apparent in the die-off on the Great Barrier Reef; some sections suffered [far worse than others.](https://theconversation.com/how-much-coral-has-died-in-the-great-barrier-reefs-worst-bleaching-event-69494) Even under huge losses, some reefs will survive. They may be remote reefs, deep reefs, temperate reefs, marginal reefs, well-protected reefs, or just plain lucky reefs. Even with so many reefs in intensive care, it’s counterproductive, and false, to call the world’s coral reefs dead.

> "… they will still be worth billions and billions …"

Coral reefs are worth (hundreds of) billions of dollars

Economists have estimated [the global value](http://www.theguardian.com/environment/2015/oct/08/coral-reefs-
worth-four-times-as-much-as-uk-economy-earth-index-finds) of the world’s coral reefs at hundreds of billions to US $1Trillion per year, due in large part to [fisheries production](http://coralreef.noaa.gov/aboutcorals/values/fisheries/), tourism, job creation, [shoreline protection](http://www.nature.com/ncomms/2014/140513/ncomms4794/full/ncomms4794.html), and the potential to discover new [medicines.](http://www.noaa.gov/features/economic_0309/medicines.html)

> "… the best time to protect a coral reef was 50 years ago …"

We can protect coral reefs starting today

This is a remix of the proverb, "The best time to plant a tree was 20 years ago. The second-best time is now."

What actions can be taken on the short term, given the long-term threats to corals? Reducing the scope of coastal development, setting and enforcing fisheries management regulations, establishing and enforcing marine protected areas, eliminating raw sewage inputs to the ocean, reducing coastal runoff of fertilizers and sediments, to name a few. There are many ways that human activity stresses coral reefs, which means many ways we can take action to [protect corals right away](https://www.iucn.org/content/despair-repair-dramatic-decline-caribbean-corals-can-be-reversed).

> "… even as we go through bleaching events more frequent and more severe …"

Corals can recover from bleaching and tissue loss

A bleached coral is still alive but very stressed. If the source of stress is reversed quickly enough, a coral may be able to re-establish its algal symbiosis, and continue to grow. Often times, bleaching causes partial tissue death, but the remaining, surviving coral polyps, can still continue to grow. At the reef scale, scientists have been surprised to see how quickly some coral reefs have bounced back from bleaching when it was a [one-time occurrence](http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sciencetech/article-2304595/Coral-reefs-heal-researchers--humans-leave-alone.html). Some corals, especially branching species, can regrow in less than 10 years. Other corals may need 100 years to regrow to the same size after suffering from partial mortality.

> “… the more stresses we take away at the local scale …”

Reducing local stress helps corals survive global stress 

Bleaching is usually triggered by a sharp rise in seawater temperature. But bleaching causes more death and damage when corals area already stressed by local factors such as fertilizer pollution, sewage pollution, overfishing, and coastal dredging. Reducing stresses at the local scale [creates resilience](https://www.iucn.org/content/despair-repair-dramatic-decline-caribbean-corals-can-be-reversed) for corals to survive global assaults like disease, climate change, and ocean acidification.

> "… new corals will be born …"

Corals can help rebuild reefs by making babies

Juvenile corals grow VERY slowly – sometimes less than 10 millimeters in a year. But this is an important source of new corals for the reefs of the future, because each juvenile adds a new combination of genes to the population, and each one has the potential to live for decades or centuries. In addition, by reproducing under modern day conditions, and making babies that survive to become juveniles on the reef, corals are evolving; they’re producing juveniles, and genetic combinations, that can live in modern day, human-influenced seas. Encouragingly, coral juveniles are also oftentime better at acclimating to new environments [compared to their parents](http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1890/13-0161.1/full). Helping corals make babies is one way that scientists are playing the long game while conservationists work to establish marine protections and stabilize the planet in the short term. Researchers around the world, including those in [my lab](https://www.marhaverlab.com) and other scientists at [CARMABI Research Station](https://www.researchstationcarmabi.org) are working on new ways to help corals survive their early life stages. [The Coral Restoration Consortium](http://www.reefresilience.org/restoration/coral-restoration-consortium/) was recently established to speed up this research in the Caribbean and beyond.

> "One of my favorite baby corals …"

Endangered corals are hanging on

The scientific name for this coral is Orbicella (formerly known as Montastraea). Orbicella is a group of three closely-related coral species that are considered endangered by the IUCN and that were all listed on the [U.S. Endangered Species list in 2014](http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/133134/0). Juveniles of this species are incredibly rare, but they can still be found.

> "… has changed our time horizon …"

What’s our time horizon for coral reef conservation? 

A time horizon is the length of time over which a plan or an investment is made. Are you saving money for next year’s vacation, or for retirement in 40 years? Your actions will be different! We use the same concepts in conservation. We can make brave decisions now to protect the oceans and stabilize the climate, knowing it will pay off in huge ways for our families, economies, and communities in the future.

> "… corals have been living on planet Earth …"

Corals have survived for hundreds of millions of years

Scientists debate the precise date when corals emerged in the oceans, but the oldest coral fossils are over [500 million years old](http://globalreefproject.com/coral-reef-history.php). The fossil record also shows us that corals became widespread in tropical seas in the middle to late Triassic, over [200 million years ago]( http://coral.aims.gov.au/info/evolution.jsp). The extinction of the dinosaurs, a time point known as the Cretaceous-Tertiary or Cretaceous-Paleogene boundary, occurred [66 million years ago](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cretaceous–Paleogene_extinction_event). Corals made it through!

> "… corals have always been playing the long game …"

Now we’re playing the long game

We‘ve lost many of the world’s most beautiful coral reefs - they won’t return to “how they were” in our lifetimes. But that’s not our goal. A few amazing, beautiful reefs still exist and [need our protection right away](http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/06/01/coral-reef-can-survive-say-scientists-fast-action-needed/). And we still have a chance to stabilize planet earth, to help damaged coral reefs grow back to their former glory, as a gift to our (great, great, great) grandchildren and to Earth herself.
